post_info.post_title: Did Kerry's staff make an honest mistake?

Jim, does it make any difference? Were you going to vote for Kerry before you read the article? Do we want to start rehashing George's military record? Why don't we jump ahead to 2004 and try to see which candidate is capable of getting us out of Iraq, then out of the middle east in general, and possible try to knock down this budget deficit. Don't you think that's a little more important than speculating on who was in a boat 35 years ago?
I don't find the error made by Kerry's staff of any great importance that would make a person change their mind on the reason they would vote for Kerry in the first place.

Jim, does it make any difference? Were you going to vote for Kerry before you read the article? Do we want to start rehashing George's military record? Why don't we jump ahead to 2004 and try to see which candidate is capable of getting us out of Iraq, then out of the middle east in general, and possible try to knock down this budget deficit. Don't you think that's a little more important than speculating on who was in a boat 35 years ago?

 
 Yes, honesty makes a difference to me. Would you hire someone who lied to you about having a college degree?
 
 No, I never had the slightest inclination to consider voting for Kerry.
 
 You can rehash any record you want as long as it exposes some question of his honesty. The National Guard is just as honorable as the full-time services.
 
 It's certainly important to consider who can do the best job as our president. I want an honest, hawkish, stand-up for defense systems president; not a deceitful, appeasing, weak-on-defense, flip-flopping, two-faced Socialist.

It's certainly important to consider who can do the best job as our president. I want an honest, hawkish, stand-up for defense systems president; not a deceitful, appeasing, weak-on-defense, flip-flopping, two-faced Socialist.

 
 At this stage I want somebody with the courage to defend the Constitution at all costs. Bush failed with the First Patriot Act.

At this stage I want somebody with the courage to defend the Constitution at all costs. Bush failed with the First Patriot Act.

 
 The Patriot Act is not going to reach out and grab you, unless you exhibit some inclinination to terrorism.

The Patriot Act is not going to reach out and grab you, unless you exhibit some inclinination to terrorism.

 
 It is naive to believe that unlimited power won't be abused. There is a reason that checks and balances were put in place. It is unacceptable for the president of the United States to support and pass laws that ignore the Bill of Rights and Constitution.
 
 Period. 
 
 I personally consider it treason. The man is either an idiot, corrupt or a coward. Or all of the above.
 
 If not dismantled the Patriot Act will do much worse than bite.

Terrorists should have no rights. It is unacceptable for terrorists to freely roam this country and cause indiscriminate death and destruction.

 
 
 OK.
 
 Where did I say I want to coddle terrorists? Care to argue against something I actually said? The Patriot Act is in direct opposition to the Constitution. Maybe you think that is OK. It is not acceptable under any circumstance to me.
 
 For the record - the Patriot Act isn't about how we treat convicted terrorists. It is about granting unlimited power to certain government agencies in their pursuit of terrorists. That is the flaw. They can use the power how they see fit - and it is absolutely fool hardy to believe it won't get misused. It has been and it will be more. The people who work for our government agencies are not so pristine to be void of human failings like greed and lust for power. To believe otherwise is beyond gullible.

 Better intelligence would help, including espionage. Are you aware that Jimmy Carter cut the number of "people on the ground", thinking that our spy satellites could do the job? Wasn't he a liberal?

I'm curious, for all those that staunchly support the Patriot Act, what is it that kept the government from doing their job effectively before passing this new act? If there was a suspected terrorist entering the country, what kept them from watching, investigating, questioning, and arresting the person before these newfound powers. These days, if you tell people you're acting in the name of fighting terrorism, they'll back you without giving it a thought. Personally, I hate to see hundreds of years of freedoms signed away with the stroke of a pen. If these government agencies would communicate with each other and do their jobs, we'll all be a lot safer. Instead, we're strip searching grandma at the airport and forfeiting our civil liberties while thousands of illegals sneak into our country from our southern borders while we sleep. I though conservatives were for smaller government?? emoticon_rolleyes

 I believe the previous administration had more detrimental effects on the communication between agencies than the present one. e.g. Jamie Gorelick, Clinton's Deputy Attorney General, who now sits on the 9-11 Commission.
 
 You must remember that 9-11 marked a substantial change in all of our outlooks on terrorism. Prior to that I think we had an idea of invulnerability to such an horrific act. We should expect drastic changes in measures aimed at detecting and monitoring terrorists.

 Jim, everything isn't about politics. It's not always a Democratic or Republican problem. Your right, it is about the previous administration, and the 5 before that one. We're like the citizens of Mayberry before the first murder was committed. All 300 million Americans were taken by suprise even though we've all read about terrorism everywhere else in the world all our lives. Now we're looking for a quick, overnight fix by giving the government veto power over every right we have ever fought for. You know what, we didn't get ourselves in this mess overnight and we can't fix it by giving our government carte blanche to step on whatever freedoms they want to in the name of national safety. We have terrorism because we meddle in the middle east. It's just that simple. As long as we keep meddling, we'll keep looking over our shoulders. I don't care how right we think we are in our causes, we will anger a certain population of that region simply by being there.
